conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the distance each object has traveled over time.
Since both objects start from the same location and move in the same direction, the distance between them will be maximized whenever the difference in their positions is greatest.
The position x(t) of an object can be found by integrating its velocity v(t).
For any two times t1 and t2, the distance between the two objects at those times is given by the absolute value of the difference in their positions, i.e., |x_A(t2) - x_B(t2)|.
At t = t1, both A and B have non-zero velocity but the velocities differ.
At t = t2, object A reaches its maximum velocity and then starts decelerating.
Object B continues to accelerate until it reaches v0 at t3.
After t2, object A decelerates and eventually stops at t4.
Object B continues to accelerate beyond v0 and maintains this speed.

premise: The maximum distance between the two objects will occur when they are moving in opposite directions or when the rate at which their distances change is minimal.
conclusion: The rate of change of the distance is zero.

premise: From the graph, the tangents at points where the velocities are equal v_A(t2) = v_B(t2) indicate these instants.
conclusion: At t2, the tangents at the points where they intersect would give us the rates of change.

premise: The maximum distance occurs just before t2, where the velocities are equal.
conclusion: At this point, the rate of change of their separation is minimized, meaning they are closest together in terms of relative motion.

premise: The rate of change of their separation is minimized at t2.
conclusion: Therefore, the two objects are farthest apart at time t2.
